guide.title: Document Management Guide
guide.subtitle: Learn how to create, approve and distribute documents step by step.

creation.title: Creating a Document
creation.step1Desc: Enter a unique document code (e.g., DOC-001), document title and optionally a description to explain the document's purpose.
creation.step2Desc: Select the document type (Procedure, Instruction, or Form) and the department that owns the document.
creation.step3Desc: If you are uploading on behalf of another department, select the preparer department. Otherwise, leave it empty.
creation.step4Desc: Choose who will prepare and initially review the document. Defaults to the person uploading, but can be changed.
creation.step5Desc: Choose who will give the final approval. Only users with Manager or Admin roles are listed.
creation.step6Desc: Choose which departments and/or individual users should receive the document after it is published.
creation.step7Desc: Set the starting revision number (default is 0). After the first revision, this number increments automatically.
creation.step8Desc: Upload the document file by dragging and dropping or clicking to browse.
creation.step9Desc: Save as Draft to continue editing later, or Submit to send the document directly into the approval workflow.

approval.title: Approval Workflow
approval.subtitle: Documents go through a two-step approval process before publishing.
approval.samePersonNote: When the preparer and approver are the same person, the preparer step is skipped automatically.
approval.rejectionNote: Rejected documents are locked. A new revision must be created to continue.

lifecycle.title: Document Lifecycle
lifecycle.subtitle: Every document revision goes through these stages:
lifecycle.draft: The revision is created as a draft. It can be edited and saved multiple times before submitting.
lifecycle.pendingApproval: The document has been submitted for approval. The assigned preparer receives a notification to review.
lifecycle.preparerApproved: The preparer has approved the document. The approver is notified for final review.
lifecycle.approved: The document has been fully approved. The approver can now publish it or request a revision.
lifecycle.published: The document is distributed to all users in the distribution list. Read tasks are created for managers.
lifecycle.preparerRejected: The preparer has rejected the document. The revision is locked and a new revision must be created.
lifecycle.approverRejected: The approver has rejected the document. The revision is locked and a new revision must be created.
lifecycle.cancelled: The document is cancelled. All related parties are notified.

revision.title: Revision System
revision.subtitle: How document revisions work:
revision.draftOverwriteDesc: If the current revision is still in Draft status, saving changes will overwrite it instead of creating a new revision.
revision.newRevisionDesc: For published or approved revisions, a new revision is created with an incremented revision number. A new file upload is required.
revision.rejectedRevisionDesc: Rejected revisions are permanently locked. You must create a new revision with updated content to continue the workflow.
revision.revisionNumberDesc: The first revision number can be set manually. All subsequent revisions are automatically numbered (+1).

afterPublish.title: What Happens After Publishing?
afterPublish.notifications: All users in the distribution list receive an email notification about the new document.
afterPublish.readTasks: Managers in the distribution list get a read task. They must open the document and confirm they have read it.
afterPublish.tracking: The document owner can track read status in real time — who has read and who hasn't.
afterPublish.reminders: Automatic reminder emails are sent to managers who haven't confirmed reading within the configured period.
afterPublish.escalation: If a manager still hasn't confirmed after the reminder period, the task is escalated to upper management.

tips.title: Tips
tips.tip1: Use meaningful document codes that follow your organization's naming convention.
tips.tip2: Add a description to help users understand the document's purpose before opening it.
tips.tip3: Select both departments and individual users in the distribution list when needed — duplicates are handled automatically.
tips.tip4: After approval, review the document one more time before publishing, as publishing triggers distribution immediately.
tips.tip5: Only managers need to confirm reading. Regular users can view published documents without confirmation.
tips.tip6: When the preparer and approver are the same person, the approval process is streamlined to a single step.
